job_title: Anonymous Employee in Owings Mills, MD
pros: Nothing. I'd give it 0 stars if I could.
cons:
University management is extremely resistant to change and refuses to make proactive decisions for the betterment of the students/staff. Requests to upgrade university tech equipment are only approved once they become an emergency. IT's management has to fight university management tooth and nail to get even minor improvements, and that's only if IT has management who's interested in improving the department.

IT staff themselves are also resistant to change, but this is probably because they're each doing the jobs of several people. The department has been hemorrhaging employees for at least 6 years and almost no replacements are being hired.

Some of the staff (fewer than there used to be, thankfully) seem to despise students, others are totally disinterested in the job satisfaction of their employees (both staff and student employees). The helpdesk is run with complete incompetence and has become a joke, providing no value to the student employees who work there, despite the student employment job being advertised as a potential internship experience. The higher-ups to the helpdesk student employees are discriminatory and utterly disinterested in attempts to improve the department or the experiences of the student employees. Minor problems are met with scolding and punishment, black male employees undeservedly taking the brunt of it. Attempts to improve the office work environment are shot down, or run into the ground before they can make progress. Student employees are expected to take on significant duties meant for staff with little, if any, increase in pay.

Promotions and raises are rarely offered, and university management fights them whenever a supervisor wants to give one . University management considers yearly increases in minimum wage to be a raise, and puts a limit of one raise per year, so it can deny any other requests for promotions/raises. Both were recently blocked entirely, despite money being wasted elsewhere.

review_title: Students were great, Administration was extremely political
job_title: Resident Director in Owings Mills, MD
pros:
The students were extremely career-focused.
The overall workplace environment and community was pleasant within my department.
cons:
Stevenson is an extremely political institution.
The pay was less than desirable.
The upper administrative team and leadership were overall selfish and greedy.
In the wake of COVID-19, everything was about the money. Safety came secondary to the dollar signs. 
Entry level staff members were used and abused.
Staff of the BIPOC community (and other marginalized groups) were tokenized often.
Students' mental health needs were not prioritized.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Owings Mills, MD
pros: Great working for the Library.

review_title: In need of some new leadership at Department levels.
job_title: Leadership in Owings Mills, MD
pros: Some very good employees that go "above and beyond" their typical jobs to try to make Stevenson great.  I believe that new President will make changes at the department levels that are needed. Rosewood complex will be helpful in recruiting and retaining students if resources are put into student union and recreation center).
cons: Leadership at department levels is lacking and in need of drastic change.  The sooner the better.  Way too many people have jobs from Villa Julie days that frankly they are no longer qualified for.  Losing a lot of talented employees because of mismanagement, poor or uncompetitive salaries, no raises in 4 years and extremely high cost of medical benefits.  There is nothing to do for students on campus (due to lack of facilities).  A student union, and student recreation center is badly needed.  Way too many adjunct faculty diminishes quality of education and resources available to students.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Stevenson, MD
pros: Good pay for adjuncts compared to other colleges and universities, pleasant campus and students
cons: Sex, age and racial discrimination, No administrative support for faculty-even blatant lies regarding promotion and job security; parking can be an issue, poorly maintained facilities depending on the department, academics take a back seat to athletics and  “perks” like new building and dining facilities, Stevenson maintains the appearance of a progressive institution rather actually being one. Depending on your sex, age and race career opportunities exist here. It’s a good place to be a white guy. Not so much for people of color and women, Different departments are different as well. If you work for a good chair, dean or department head, you can be ok, but overall, profit rules here. And it mostly profits white guys.

review_title: Great opportunities at a fast growing institution
job_title: in Stevenson, MD
pros: Small university with a very bright future.  There are many positions that will be available in the future due to the growth at the university.  There is good support for professional development and a wide latitude to be able to initiate your own ideas and programs.
cons: Depends on the department.  Certain VPs are not up to par in terms of understanding and experience, and can reverse decisions at their level and make you look bad without your input or consideration for your logic.  I suppose this is no different than any employer, but it seems more prevalent here.  Generally direct supervisors are high quality

job_title: in Stevenson, MD
pros: Talent is recognized, and I have the freedom to accomplish my goals without interference. The fairly recent emphasis on wellness is a definite plus: we are offered free yoga classes and have access to the athletic facilties.
cons: Fast growth can sometimes create communication obstacles. The dual campus environment can contribute to this challenge. Not everyone on the staff pays enough attention to email, though it is slowly getting better.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Owings Mills, MD
pros: Progressive organization that is very student centered. The Environmental Science program is excellent. Very good that the Rosewood property was obtained.
cons: There's a need for more green space. Acquisition of the Rosewood property will help in the green space issue. Owings Mills campus looks too much like a business park and not a college.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Baltimore, MD
pros: Stevenson is a great university to work for. Many departments view you as a valuable member of the administrative team and there are lots of opportunities to mentor students as part of your work. The vacation benefits are amazing and this helps outweigh the lower salary of traditional higher education support positions.
cons: Higher education is in a bit of a crisis right now. Support salaries are lower than other industries and budgets are tight so there is not much left for professional development or other "perks."

review_title: Adjunct Contract not Renew without Warning
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Beautiful campus, competitive pay.
cons: I was teaching as an adjunct and was given no warning that I was not scheduled any courses for the upcoming semester until I tried to upload my syllabus.

job_title: Tutor in Stevenson, MD
pros: I was able to make my schedule exactly how I wanted it. There are measures in place to ensure that students who neglect their appointments are dealt with.
cons: You don't get paid if a student cancels his/her tutoring appointment. They seem to cycle new management in constantly because they've been so bad.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Owings Mills, MD
pros: I've been at Stevenson University for over 20 years, and started when it was was still Villa Julie College.  It is an excellent environment and a great place to work.  The workplace culture is very professional but also very warm.  Even as a part-time employee, I am engaged and included in the culture.
cons: Cannot think of any down sides to my work at Stevenson.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Owings Mills, MD
pros: The campus atmosphere is great. You’ll meet some cool people
cons: No cons to overall University. Issues with specific department. Gives professional development but there’s no room for growth.  Very numbers oriented, which is the hardest thing for me to grasp. I’m more focused on the best interest for the student.

job_title: Conference Services Student Worker in Owings Mills, MD
pros: Stevenson is a great company to work for.
cons: Stevenson should provide a review for all student employees about how the performance of their supervisors is. Also, there should be mandatory random urine analysis tests conducted for student employees as well. Saw many students either under the influence or high on the job.

job_title: in Owings Mills, MD

review_title: Complacency at its finest, no growth opportunities, lack of diversity
job_title: Assistant Director, Public Relations in Owings Mills, MD
pros: If you want an easy 9-5 where you're normally bored most days then this is the place for you. A lot of time off with snow days, holidays and then down time during winter and summer breaks.
cons: No growth opportunities (compensation or training) and lack of diversity, especially in leadership. Stevenson is the definition of good ole boys club. Members of leadership often lack experience and professionalism. Turnover is high here for a reason.

job_title: Tutore in Owings Mills, MD

cons: Some people want you to do their work for them. Dealing with difficult people sometimes.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Baltimore, MD
pros: Great benefits and a Wellness Program that includes fitness, healthy food demonstrations, and free flu shots.
cons: Benefits do not include tuition remission for graduate degrees. This benefit is only available to certain people. Most executive level employees are unfriendly and look down upon employees. Many times, they don't even speak. Used to have a community feel but has changed tremendously. Too top heavy!
